awd_titl_txt: Inclusion at Robotics: Science and Systems 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports travel for students in robotics to participate in the Robotics: Science and Systems (RSS) conference, along with its associated workshops in 2020 at the Oregon Sate University.  The students will be mentored both through being paired with senior PhD students and postdocs and participation in a mentorship event led by the RSS conference chair. By exposing early career researchers, including those from underrepresented groups, to this type of intellectual environment, they will be better able to be situated in the robotics field and get better ideas for the type and quality of research needed to have impact in the field.

This project supports travel for students in robotics. Awardees of these travel grants will fill out post conference surveys to help measure the effects of attending the conference.  Analysis of the responses will help tailor future travel awards.  One goal of these travel grants is to expand the pool of future researchers to have a more diverse set of backgrounds than is currently typically found amongst researchers in robotics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this award was to support students attending Robotics: Science and Systems (RSS) thereby increasing the number of new conference participants from groups traditionally underrepresented in robotics. Fellowships were awarded to selected students, prioritizing BSc, MSc, and first and second year PhD students. Priority was also given to students who had not previously attended RSS and/or were new to the robotics research community. 

 

Inclusion@RSS fellows received complimentary registration, accommodations, and travel to the 2022 RSS conference that took place at Columbia University in New York City, New York on June 27 - July 1, 2022. Furthermore, each fellow was assigned a senior member of the robotics community as a mentor, and fellows engaged in a mentorship program. The program consisted of several sessions designed to help new researchers navigate an international conference. Fellows were first introduced to each other and provided with information on "how to conference" in a virtual session the week before RSS. They were also encouraged to connect via Zoom with their assigned mentor. During the conference, students had a welcome breakfast and panel session on the morning of the first workshop day, to help them integrate into the conference activities. Finally, students were again encouraged to meet with their mentor (either in person, if the mentor was at RSS, or virtually if they are not) to check in.

 

This award supported 15 early career researchers; fellows got to be a part of the robotics community, felt prepared and supported, and built bonds with each other. 

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2023
Modified by: Hadas Kress Gazit
